body.p:
To his Excellency
Thomas E Bramlett
Governor of Kentucky

The undersigned Claiborne Lisle respectfully represents that on the of May 1861 he became bound in a Recognisance Bond for as the surety of Wm W Baldwin for said Baldwin's appearance in the Clark Circuit Court to answer an Indictment pending in said Court whereon he was charged with Gaming, the charge being that $2000, dollars were won and lost withing 24 hours- the Penalty of the Bond being for $1000= and for his appearance at the July Term 1861= of said Court, he did appear at that Term_ but case was continued for Commonwealth at the term and also at the succeeding term_ of May ^November^ 1861_ May 1862- & July 1862= until finaly at the November Term 1862= the said Baldwin not being present was the Bond was declared forfeited_ and at the May Term 1863 Judgment rendered on the Bond against the undersigned for the sum of one thousand Dollars.
Said Baldwin had always operated and that he was innocent of the change against him & which Petitioner beleived his assertions.

In the fall of 1862_ Baldwin went into the Confederate service, and was not in Clark County at the November ^term^ 1862, he was killed in July 1863, leaving a small Estate in Clark County and also a wife
and six Infant children_ it is not certain that the Estate left by him would be ^is^ sufficient to indemnify this Petitioner but if it is, or to the extent that it may afford indemnity would affect said wife & childred. To the end therefore that they may be saved from that loss and your Petitioner releaved from the aforesaid Judgment he prays for the interpostition of your Excellency_ and the remission of the aforesaid Judgment

Jany 27 1864.
Clairborne Lisle
Clark County Ky
Sworn to before me this 27th of January 1864 by Claiborne Lisle-
A H Buckner ck
The undersigned citizens of Clark County Kentucky respectfully request that Claiborne Lisle may be released from the payment of the Judgment referred to in the foregoing Petition - Jany 27th 1864

John W. Laughlin
E T Woodward
Ambrose G Bush
Chas. Chase
Chas Poston
John Clinhinheard
Robt. Barker
William Garner
Benjamin Turner
Wm F Pool
John Williams
W C Sumper
N B Gentry
R. S.
J H Ogden
E S Jonett
John E Gordon
Geo E Gordon

I was engaged by Baldwin to defend him in the case named above & in a about it which was settled- I believe the facts are correctly stated in the Petition. Mrs. Baldwin & her children are clever & it will press them sorely to pay the full judgement For that sake I recommend a remission as far as you can- ^I believe the gameing charged was a frolick & show^
Jno. B. Huston

I am acquainted with Mrs Baldwin and family and am of opinion that it would operate very sorely upon them to collect the forfeiture as stated by the Petitioner Wm Lisle I know nothing of the maters of the Petition farther but am well satisfied, that if your Excellency will interpose clemency in a case of the merit of this character, that this case is one that should be remitted

I consider this case viewed in all its aspects, as one that is entitled to executive clemency, as the enforcement of the penalty of the Bond would operate as a punishment of an innocent widow and her children, who have but a small estate, and who by the enforcement of the penalty would be rendered nearly if not wholly destitute
James Simpson
I concur with Judge Simpson in the above statement
B F Buckner
I am well acquainted with Mrs Baldwin & family & I fully concur with Judge Simpson in opinion as above stated
Sam G Stuart

I understand that the estate of W. Baldwin dec. in not likely to be sufficient to pay all the legal claims against it and if the Bond on which C. Lisle is security be enforced_ creditors will lose, and the widow & children be in very destitute circumstances_ I think that it will be well for Your Excellency to give due consideration, in the manifestation of clemency not to Lisle but to the benefit of Mrs. Baldwin, her children & the creditors of his estate
respectfully J. M. Ogden

Petition of C Lisle for Remission of Judgt in W W Baldwins case
Genl Huston, Judge Simpson, Judge Bush ^J M Ogden, S G Stuart Sheriff^ & Mr Buckner are too well known to require any commendation

The signers to the general Petition are all Union Men of the very best character and standing, and from the interest & feeling evinced almost every clever man in the county would readily sign it if necessary
I know the application to be meritorious- and desire that the prayer of the Petition be granted

May the 12th 1864
Chas Eginton
W T Downey Atty for Commonwealth authorise me to say that he recommends the case of Mrs Baldwin for favorable consideration
Jno B. Huston

Clark Cir Ct
vs
C Lisle
$1000-
Forfeiture
Remit except fees & costs
Tho E Bramlette
25th May/64
